thread.title: Indiana 115, Detroit 112: Kentavious Caldwell-Pope stars in exhibition
thread.title_full: Indiana 115, Detroit 112: Kentavious Caldwell-Pope stars in exhibition

author: freep.com
title: Indiana 115, Detroit 112: Kentavious Caldwell-Pope stars in exhibition
text:
MORE Stanley Johnson didn’t want to talk about the 26 points.
He wanted to focus on the errors in the 115-112 loss to the Indiana Pacers in Tuesday night’s exhibition opener at the Palace.
“I think there were three plays that really stood out that I think lost the game for us,” Johnson said in the home locker room afterward. “My two turnovers at the top of the court and then I got (beat for a lay-up) with two seconds, three seconds left on the shot clock.”
But since the game doesn’t count, the fans can focus on the good – Johnson looking every bit ready to contribute to the Pistons at the tender young age of 19.
Not that it’s surprising. He has passed every hurdle since the Pistons used the eighth pick of June’s NBA draft on the Arizona standout.
He entered the game late in the first quarter and hit his first shot. He was forced to play point guard with the Pistons missing Reggie Jackson (sore Achilles) and Steve Blake (concussion).
He finished the first half with 11 points, but with Spencer Dinwiddie struggling with ineffective play and foul trouble, Johnson got the start in the second half.
He scored 15 points and he was forced to guard red-hot Pacers standout Paul George, who finished with 32 points, 20 coming in the first quarter.
Johnson was referring to having his pocket picked twice by Pacers backup Toney Douglas.

Observations from Pistons' preseason opener
But overall a solid debut.
“Playing against a superstar in Paul George and seeing what that’s like is always positive and just playing on the court,” Johnson said.
“I think knowledge is power and your best teacher is experience. The more experience I get, the faster I learn, the faster I can be great.”
KCP Excels: The few fans who showed up at the Palace were able to see Kentavious Caldwell-Pope’s hard work pay off.
The third-year guard put on a shooting display in knocking down his first six three-pointers on his way to 22 points.
Pistons coach Stan Van Gundy said Caldwell-Pope has been the Pistons’ best player in camp and it carried over to Tuesday night.
He got things started with a stellar first-quarter, when he was 4-for-4 from three-point range.
He was 4-for-5 to score 14 points in the first quarter and even his miss showed growth.
He was closely guarded by a Pacers defender, but he was able to make a move and get all the way to the rim.
His lay-up attempt barely missed, but Andre Drummond was able to get the follow-up dunk off the offensive rebound.
Caldwell-Pope had poor ball-handling skills when he was a rookie in the 2013-14 season and he now appears comfortable dribbling in traffic.
Spencer Struggles: Dinwiddie got the start alongside Caldwell-Pope, Drummond, Ersan Ilyasova and Marcus Morris.
He was able to find Ilyasova for the first basket of the game, but the Pistons’ pick-and-roll attack was noticeably hindered.
Van Gundy constantly harped about Dinwiddie’s performance, even calling time-out after one misstep.
Johnson had a plus-minus of plus-8.
Dinwiddie was minus-18 and scored four points on 1-for-6 shooting. He had four assists, but three turnovers in 25 minutes.
Van Gundy’s options were limited.
“Spence has been OK in camp, but he just didn’t have a good game,” Van Gundy said. “He didn’t play well. He fouled a lot, missed defensive assignments, turned the ball over.
“He made a couple of nice plays offensively, but he just didn’t have a good night.”
Bullock's Time: Van Gundy made a point of getting a look at swingman Reggie Bullock in the playing rotation.
He didn’t enter the game until the second half, where he got the start, but contributed nicely when he entered.
The Pistons are over the roster limit of 15 and Bullock, who was acquired from the Phoenix Suns in the off-season, is on the roster bubble.
But Tuesday was a good night for Bullock, 24.
He was active on defense as he got time at shooting guard.
But the key for Bullock is to make shots and he knocked down two three-pointers as the Pistons surged.
Injury List: The MRI on Jackson’s Achilles was clean. Swingman Adonis Thomas (Achilles) and center Aron Baynes (ankle) also were not available.
“Baynes went through walk-through today, but until he can get through a practice, I’m not gonna throw him into a game,” Van Gundy said.
